Shane is referring to the singleton design pattern. You should really buy
"Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software" by Erich
Gamma, et al.  Amazon has a deal where you can get the refactoring book by
Martin Fowler at the same time -- also an excellent book. Both are
prerequisite reading on this newsgroup.

Here's something I pulled off the web to tide you over while FedEx ships it
to you overnight...
you can search for more if you want:
http://members.tripod.com/rwald/java/articles/Singleton_in_Java.html

Link to Amazon for convenience (you can prob get it cheaper elsewhere):
http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0201633612/qid=1005620706/sr=2-1/ref=
sr_2_3_1/102-8985390-4476123

Chris

Thanks.  Yes, I understand why the methods have to be static.  I'm 
just looking for a way around that requirement, since all of the 
methods that I want to call within oneTimeSetup() and oneTimeTearDown
() are *not* static and are existing castor framework code to build 
up and delete data for my test cases.  I just want to call this 
pretty significant setup and tear down code just once and use it for 
all of my test cases verses for every testXXX() method via the 
regular setup() and tearDown() methods.  

What do you mean by "you can always create a singleton"?

thanks,
chad.
